aback.meaning: Toward the back or rear; backward.
aback.example: He was taken aback by the sudden change in her attitude.

abase.meaning: To lower in rank, dignity, or esteem; to humiliate or degrade.
abase.example: He refused to abase himself in front of his rivals.

abate.meaning: To reduce in degree, intensity, or amount; to diminish.
abate.example: The storm began to abate after several hours of heavy rain.

abbey.meaning: A building or complex of buildings used by a community of monks or nuns.
abbey.example: The abbey stood majestically atop the hill.

abbot.meaning: The superior or head of an abbey or monastery.
abbot.example: The newly appointed abbot decided to take a tour of the abbey with the cardinal's emissary.

abhor.meaning: To regard with extreme disgust or hatred; to detest.
abhor.example: I absolutely abhor being stuck in traffic jams.

abide.meaning: To accept or endure something patiently; to remain or continue.
abide.example: He promised to abide by the rules of the agreement.

abled.meaning: (In combination) Having a specified range of physical or mental abilities.
abled.example: The abled athletes competed alongside their peers in the marathon.

abode.meaning: A place of residence; a home.
abode.example: They invited us to their humble abode for dinner.

abort.meaning: To terminate prematurely, especially a process or operation.
abort.example: The mission was aborted due to technical difficulties.

about.meaning: In the vicinity; around; concerning or regarding something.
about.example: He wandered about the garden, enjoying the flowers.

above.meaning: In a higher position; overhead; superior to.
above.example: The plane flew above the clouds.

abuse.meaning: Improper or harmful use of something; mistreatment.
abuse.example: All abuse, whether physical, verbal, psychological, or sexual, is unacceptable.

abyss.meaning: A deep or seemingly bottomless chasm; a profound depth.
abyss.example: The explorers peered into the dark abyss below.

acorn.meaning: The fruit of an oak tree, a nut enclosed in a woody cupule.
acorn.example: Squirrels gathered acorns in preparation for the winter.

acrid.meaning: Having an irritatingly strong and unpleasant taste or smell.
acrid.example: The acrid smell of burning rubber filled the air.

actor.meaning: A person who performs in plays, movies, or television shows.
actor.example: The actor gave an outstanding performance in the film.

acute.meaning: Sharp or severe in effect; intense; brief but intense in duration.
acute.example: She experienced acute pain after twisting her ankle.

adage.meaning: An old saying which has obtained credit by long use.
adage.example: The adage 'What goes around, comes around' is often quoted.

adapt.meaning: To make suitable for a particular purpose or situation; to adjust.
adapt.example: She had to adapt to the new environment when she moved to the city.

adept.meaning: One fully skilled or well-versed in something; a proficient.
adept.example: She is an adept violinist, performing in prestigious orchestras.

admin.meaning: Administration, or administrative work; to serve as an administrator for or of.
admin.example: There's a lot of admin involved in the birth of a child.

admit.meaning: To allow to enter; to grant entrance (to), whether into a place, into the mind, or into consideration.
admit.example: A ticket admits one into a playhouse.

adobe.meaning: An unburnt brick dried in the sun, used for building.
adobe.example: Many people in Texas and New Mexico live in adobe houses.

adopt.meaning: To take by choice into a relationship (a child, heir, friend, citizen, etc.).
adopt.example: They decided to adopt a child after years of infertility struggles.

adore.meaning: To regard with deep, intense love or admiration.
adore.example: She absolutely adores her grandmother and visits her every weekend.

adorn.meaning: To make more beautiful or attractive; to decorate.
adorn.example: The walls of the room were adorned with beautiful paintings.

adult.meaning: A fully grown human or animal; fully grown.
adult.example: At 18, she was officially considered an adult.

affix.meaning: That which is affixed; an appendage; to attach.
affix.example: Please affix your signature to the bottom of the form.

afire.meaning: On fire, often used metaphorically to indicate passion or enthusiasm.
afire.example: Her eyes were afire with excitement after hearing the good news.

afoot.example: There are plans afoot to renovate the old library.

afoul.meaning: In a state of collision or entanglement, especially in nautical contexts.
afoul.example: The ships’ lines and sails were all afoul, causing a delay in their journey.

after.meaning: Later; next, following; behind in time or sequence.
after.example: He went for a walk after finishing his homework.

again.meaning: Another time; once more; (obsolete or dialectal) Against.
again.example: He promised to try again after taking a break.

agape.meaning: In a state of astonishment, wonder, expectation, or eager attention; with mouth hanging open.
agape.example: The audience was agape as the magician performed his final trick.

agate.meaning: A semi-pellucid, uncrystallized variety of quartz, presenting various tints in the same specimen, with colors delicately arranged in stripes or bands.
agate.example: The jewelry was adorned with beautiful agate stones.

agent.meaning: One who exerts power or has the power to act; a representative.
agent.example: The agent handled all the contract negotiations on behalf of the client.

agile.meaning: Having the ability to move quickly and easily; nimble.
agile.example: An agile creature like the cheetah can outrun most predators.

aging.meaning: To cause to grow old; to become older or more mature.
aging.example: Grief ages us more than time itself.

aglow.example: Her face was aglow with happiness after hearing the good news.

agony.meaning: Extreme pain or suffering, particularly physical or emotional.
agony.example: The agony of losing a loved one is beyond words.

agora.meaning: A place for gathering, especially in ancient Greece.
agora.example: The citizens met in the agora to discuss the city's issues.

agree.meaning: To harmonize in opinion, statement, or action; to concur.
agree.example: All parties agree in the expediency of the law.

ahead.meaning: In or to the front; in advance; onward.
ahead.example: We have a long journey ahead of us.

aider.example: The aide provided support to the students during the exam.

aisle.meaning: A wing of a building, notably in a church, separated from the nave by piers.
aisle.example: She walked down the aisle in a beautiful white dress.

alarm.meaning: A summons to arms, as on the approach of an enemy; to call to arms for defense.
alarm.example: The soldiers sprang into action at the sound of the alarm.

album.meaning: A book specially designed to keep photographs, stamps, or autographs.
album.example: She showed me her photo album from her trip to Europe.

alert.meaning: An alarm; attentive, awake, on guard.
alert.example: The guards remained alert throughout the night.

algae.meaning: Any of many aquatic photosynthetic organisms, including seaweeds, whose size ranges from a single cell to giant kelps.
algae.example: The pond was covered with a layer of green algae.

alibi.meaning: A plea or defense under which a person proves being in another place when the alleged crime was committed.
alibi.example: He provided a solid alibi that proved he was at the party when the crime occurred.

alien.meaning: Any life form of extraterrestrial or extradimensional origin; foreign, not belonging to the same country.
alien.example: The scientists were excited to discover evidence of alien life on the distant planet.

align.meaning: To form a line or fall into a line; to arrange or adjust in proper position.
align.example: The workers aligned the bricks perfectly for the new wall.

alike.meaning: Having resemblance or similarity; in the same manner or degree.
alike.example: The twins looked so alike that even their parents had trouble telling them apart.

alive.meaning: Having life; living; not dead; (used attributively) having life.
alive.example: As long as the plant is alive, he will continue to water it.

allay.meaning: To calm, soothe, or alleviate; to put at rest.
allay.example: Her kind words helped allay his fears about the surgery.

alley.meaning: A narrow street or passageway, especially one giving access to the rear of buildings.
alley.example: The parking lot to my friend's apartment building is in the alley.

allot.meaning: To distribute or apportion by (or as if by) lot.
allot.example: They allotted the tasks evenly among the team members.

allow.meaning: To grant, give, admit, accord, or yield; to let one have.
allow.example: The teacher allowed the students to leave early on Friday.

alloy.meaning: A metal that is a combination of two or more elements, at least one of which is a metal.
alloy.example: Bronze is an alloy made of copper and tin.

aloft.meaning: At, to, or in the air or sky.
aloft.example: The kite flew high aloft in the clear blue sky.

alone.meaning: By oneself, solitary; apart from or exclusive of others.
alone.example: I can't ask for help because I am alone.

along.meaning: In company; together; by the length of; in a line with the length of; lengthwise next to.
along.example: John played the piano and everyone sang along.

aloof.meaning: Reserved and remote; either physically or emotionally distant; standoffish; at or from a distance, but within view, or at a small distance; apart; away.
aloof.example: She remained aloof from the rest of the group.

aloud.meaning: Spoken out loud; with a loud voice, or great noise; loudly; audibly.
aloud.example: He read the poem aloud to the class.

alpha.meaning: The name of the first letter of the Greek alphabet (Α, α), followed by beta. In the Latin alphabet, it is the predecessor to A; designates the first in an order of precedence.
alpha.example: He was the alpha of the team, leading everyone with confidence.

altar.meaning: A table or similar flat-topped structure used for religious rites.
altar.example: They knelt at the altar to pray.

alter.meaning: To change the form or structure of.
alter.example: She decided to alter her dress for the party.

amass.meaning: A large number of things collected or piled together; to collect into a mass or heap.
amass.example: Over the years, he amassed a collection of rare books.

amaze.meaning: Amazement, astonishment; to fill with wonder and surprise; to astonish, astound, surprise, or perplex.
amaze.example: The magician's tricks never failed to amaze the audience.

amber.meaning: Ambergris, the waxy product of the sperm whale; to perfume or flavour with ambergris; of a brownish-yellow colour, like that of most amber.

amble.meaning: An unhurried leisurely walk or stroll; to stroll or walk slowly and leisurely.
amble.example: We decided to amble through the park on a sunny afternoon.

amend.meaning: (usually in the plural) An act of righting a wrong; compensation; to make better; improve.
amend.example: He amended the document before sending it to the client.

amiss.meaning: Fault; wrong; an evil act, a bad deed; wrong; faulty; out of order; improper or otherwise incorrect; wrongly.
amiss.example: Something seems amiss with the machine.

amity.meaning: Friendship; the cooperative and supportive relationship between people or animals, which involves mutual knowledge, esteem, affection, and respect.
amity.example: Their amity lasted through many years of friendship.

among.meaning: Denotes a mingling or intermixing with distinct or separable objects.
among.example: How can you speak with authority about their customs when you have never lived among them?

ample.meaning: Large; great in size, extent, capacity, or bulk; spacious, roomy, or widely extended.
ample.example: The house had ample space for all of our belongings.

amply.example: The dessert was amply sweet for everyone's taste.

amuse.meaning: To entertain or occupy in a pleasant manner; to stir with pleasing emotions.
amuse.example: The comedian's jokes amused the audience.

angel.meaning: An incorporeal and sometimes divine messenger from a deity, often depicted as a youthful winged figure in flowing robes; to support by donating money.
angel.example: She was an angel, always helping others in need.

anger.meaning: A strong feeling of displeasure, hostility, or antagonism towards someone or something; to cause such a feeling.
anger.example: You need to control your anger.

angle.meaning: A figure formed by two rays which start from a common point (a plane angle) or by three planes that intersect (a solid angle); (often in the passive) to place (something) at an angle.
angle.example: The angle between the two walls was 90 degrees.

angry.example: An angry mob started looting the warehouse.

angst.meaning: Emotional turmoil; painful sadness; to suffer angst; to fret.
angst.example: The character's angst was evident throughout the film.

anime.meaning: An artistic style originating in, and associated with, Japanese animation, and that has also been adopted by a comparatively low number of animated works from other countries.
anime.example: I enjoy watching anime series in my free time.

ankle.meaning: The skeletal joint which connects the foot with the leg; the uppermost portion of the foot and lowermost portion of the leg, which contain this skeletal joint; to walk.
ankle.example: She twisted her ankle while running.

annex.example: They built an annex to the main building.

annoy.meaning: A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what one dislikes; to disturb or irritate, especially by continued or repeated acts; to bother with unpleasant deeds.
annoy.example: The loud noise from the construction site began to annoy me.

annul.meaning: To formally revoke the validity of.
annul.example: The contract was annulled after the breach of terms.

anode.meaning: An electrode, of a cell or other electrically polarized device, through which a positive current of electricity flows inwards (and thus, electrons flow outwards). It can have either a negative or a positive voltage.
anode.example: The anode is part of the electrochemical reaction in the battery.

antic.meaning: A grotesque representation of a figure; a gargoyle; to perform antics, caper; playful, funny, absurd; having existed in ancient times, descended from antiquity; used especially in reference to Greece and Rome.
antic.example: The clown's antics kept the children entertained.

anvil.meaning: A heavy iron block used in the blacksmithing trade as a surface upon which metal can be struck and shaped; to fashion on an anvil (often used figuratively).
anvil.example: The blacksmith hammered the iron on the anvil.

aorta.meaning: The great artery which carries the blood from the heart to all parts of the body except the lungs; the main trunk of the arterial system.
aorta.example: The surgeon repaired the damaged aorta during the operation.

apart.meaning: (Used after a noun or in the predicate) Exceptional, distinct; placed separately (in regard to space or time).
apart.example: They were worlds apart in their ideas.

aphid.meaning: Sapsucking pest insect of the superfamily Aphidoidea; an aphidian.
aphid.example: The aphids infested the roses in the garden.

aping.meaning: To behave like an ape; foolish imitation or mimicry.
aping.example: He was aping the behavior of the celebrity he admired.

apnea.example: Sleep apnea can disrupt a person's rest.

apple.meaning: A common, round fruit produced by the tree Malus domestica, cultivated in temperate climates; to become apple-like.
apple.example: She ate an apple as an afternoon snack.

apply.meaning: To lay or place; to put (one thing to another).
apply.example: You should apply sunscreen before going outside.

apron.meaning: An article of clothing worn over the front of the torso and/or legs for protection from spills; also historically worn by Freemasons and as part of women's fashion; to cover with, or as if with, an apron.
apron.example: She wore an apron to protect her clothes while cooking.

aptly.meaning: In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; appropriately.
aptly.example: The book was aptly titled 'The Silent Observer.'

arbor.meaning: A shady sitting place or pergola usually in a park or garden, surrounded by climbing shrubs, vines or other vegetation.
arbor.example: We sat in the arbor, enjoying the breeze.

ardor.meaning: Great warmth of feeling; fervor; passion.
ardor.example: His ardor for the project inspired the whole team.

arena.meaning: An enclosed area, often outdoor, for the presentation of sporting events (sports arena) or other spectacular events; earthen area, often oval, specifically for rodeos (North America) or circular area for bullfights (especially Hispanic America).
arena.example: A large crowd filled the seats of the arena.

argue.meaning: To show grounds for concluding (that); to indicate, imply.
argue.example: They argue that the policy will benefit the economy.

arise.meaning: To come up from a lower to a higher position.
arise.example: He arose from his chair to speak.

armor.meaning: A protective layer over a body, vehicle, or other object intended to deflect or diffuse damaging forces; to equip something with armor or a protective coating or hardening.
armor.example: The knight donned his armor before battle.

aroma.meaning: A smell; especially a pleasant spicy or fragrant one.
aroma.example: The aroma of freshly baked bread filled the kitchen.

arose.meaning: To come up from a lower to a higher position.
arose.example: A storm arose suddenly in the afternoon.

array.meaning: Clothing and ornamentation; to clothe and ornament; to adorn or attire.
array.example: The guests were arrayed in formal attire.

arrow.meaning: A projectile consisting of a shaft, a point, and a tail with stabilizing fins that is shot from a bow; to move swiftly and directly (like an arrow).
arrow.example: The archer released the arrow with great precision.

arson.meaning: The crime of deliberately starting a fire with intent to cause damage; to illegally set fire to; to burn down in a criminal manner.
arson.example: The suspect was arrested for arson after the fire was traced to his actions.

artsy.meaning: (sometimes derogatory) Inclined towards the arts; arty.
artsy.example: The gallery was full of artsy people discussing modern paintings.

ascot.example: He wore a formal ascot to the gala.

ashen.meaning: Made from the wood of the ash-tree.
ashen.example: An ashen bow and quiver of arrows beside.

aside.meaning: An incidental remark made quietly so as to be heard by the person to whom it is said and not by any others in the vicinity; to or on one side so as to be out of the way.
aside.example: He made a comment aside, only for his friend to hear.

askew.meaning: Turned or twisted to one side; tilted to one side.
askew.example: The picture was hanging askew on the wall.

assay.example: The scientist will assay the new method to determine its effectiveness.

asset.meaning: Something or someone of any value; any portion of one's property or effects so considered.
asset.example: These shares are a valuable asset.

atoll.meaning: A type of island consisting of a ribbon reef that nearly or entirely surrounds a lagoon and supports, in most cases, one to many islets on the reef platform. Atolls have a unique geology, so not all islands with a reef and a lagoon are atolls.
atoll.example: The tropical island was part of an atoll.

atone.meaning: To make reparation, compensation, amends, or satisfaction for an offense, crime, mistake, or deficiency.
atone.example: He sought to atone for his past mistakes.

attic.meaning: The space, often unfinished and with sloped walls, directly below the roof in the uppermost part of a house or other building, generally used for storage or habitation.
attic.example: We went up to the attic to look for the boxes containing our childhood keepsakes.

audio.meaning: A sound, or a sound signal; focused on audible sound, as opposed to sight.
audio.example: I need to adjust the audio settings for the movie.

audit.meaning: A judicial examination; to examine and adjust (e.g., an account).
audit.example: The company hired an expert to audit their financial records.

augur.meaning: A diviner who foretells events by the behaviour of birds or other animals, or by signs derived from celestial phenomena, or unusual occurrences; to foretell events; to exhibit signs of future events.
augur.example: The astrologer tried to augur the future based on the stars.

aunty.meaning: The sister or sister-in-law of one’s parent; term of familiarity or respect for a middle-aged or elderly woman.
aunty.example: Aunty Mary is coming over for dinner.

avail.meaning: Effect in achieving a goal or aim; purpose, use (now usually in negative constructions); to turn to the advantage of.
avail.example: I tried fixing it, to no avail. Labor, without economy, is of little avail.

avert.example: To avert the eyes from an object.

avian.meaning: A bird; characteristic of or pertaining to birds, or to bird-like or flying creatures.
avian.example: The avian species in the forest are diverse.

avoid.meaning: To try not to meet or communicate with (a person); to shun.
avoid.example: He tries to avoid confrontations at all costs.

await.meaning: A waiting for; ambush; to wait for.
await.example: We await your response with great anticipation.

awake.example: I woke up and was instantly awake, alert to the sounds around me.

award.meaning: A judgment, sentence, or final decision; to give by sentence or judicial determination; to assign or apportion, after careful regard to the nature of the case; to adjudge.
award.example: She won the award for best actress at the ceremony.

aware.meaning: Vigilant or on one's guard against danger or difficulty.
aware.example: Stay aware! Don't let your guard down.

awash.meaning: Washed by the waves or tide (of a rock or strip of shore, or of an anchor, etc., when flush with the surface of the water, so that the waves break over it); covered with water.
awash.example: The shore was awash with the tide, leaving no trace of footprints.

awoke.meaning: To become conscious after having slept.
awoke.example: She awoke from her nap feeling refreshed.

axial.meaning: A flight feather that appears between the primaries and secondaries on some birds; relating to, resembling, or situated on an axis.
axial.example: The bird's axial feathers help with balance during flight.

axiom.meaning: A seemingly self-evident or necessary truth which is based on assumption; a principle or proposition which cannot actually be proved or disproved.
axiom.example: It is an axiom that light travels faster than sound.

axion.meaning: A hypothetical subatomic particle postulated to resolve certain symmetry problems concerning the strong nuclear force.
axion.example: The discovery of the axion would help explain certain mysteries in physics.

azure.meaning: A blue colour on a coat of arms, represented in engraving by horizontal parallel lines; to colour blue; sky blue; resembling the clear blue colour of the unclouded sky.
azure.example: The sky was a perfect azure as the sun set.

bacon.meaning: Cured meat from the sides, belly or back of a pig.
bacon.example: I love a crispy slice of bacon for breakfast.

badge.meaning: A distinctive mark, token, sign, emblem or cognizance, worn on one's clothing, as an insignia of some rank, or of the membership of an organization; to mark or distinguish with a badge.
badge.example: She proudly wore the badge of her achievements.

badly.meaning: Ill, unwell; in a bad manner.
badly.example: He's never badly hurt in any of his adventures.

bagel.meaning: A toroidal bread roll that is boiled before it is baked; to achieve a score of 6-0 in a tennis set.
bagel.example: She grabbed a bagel for breakfast on her way to work.

baggy.meaning: Of clothing, very loose-fitting, so as to hang away from the body.
baggy.example: She wore baggy jeans that were comfortable for lounging.

baker.meaning: A person who bakes and sells bread, cakes, and similar items.
baker.example: The baker is famous for his freshly baked pastries.

baler.meaning: A machine for creating bales, e.g., of hay or cotton.
baler.example: Farmer Jones is in straits because his baler is broken down and he's got three fields of hay ready to bale.

balmy.example: The evening air was balmy and warm.

banal.meaning: Common in a boring way, to the point of being predictable; containing nothing new or fresh.
banal.example: The movie was so banal, offering nothing original or exciting.

banjo.meaning: A stringed musical instrument (chordophone), usually with a round body, a membrane-like soundboard, and a fretted neck, played by plucking or strumming the strings; to play a banjo.
banjo.example: He strummed his banjo while singing folk songs.

barge.meaning: A large flat-bottomed towed or self-propelled boat used mainly for river and canal transport of heavy goods or bulk cargo; to intrude or break through, particularly in an unwelcome or clumsy manner.
barge.example: The cargo was loaded onto the barge for transport.

baron.meaning: The male ruler of a barony.
baron.example: The baron ruled over the lands with great power.

basal.meaning: Base, bottom, minimum; basic, elementary; relating to, or forming, the base, or point of origin.
basal.example: The basal layer of the skin is where new cells are produced.

basic.meaning: A necessary commodity, a staple requirement; necessary, essential for life or some process.
basic.example: Rice is a basic for many Asian villagers.

basil.meaning: A plant (Ocimum basilicum), often used as a herb in cooking.
basil.example: I added fresh basil to the salad for extra flavor.

basin.meaning: A wide bowl for washing, sometimes affixed to a wall; To create a concavity or depression in.
basin.example: She filled the basin with water to wash her hands.

basis.meaning: A physical base or foundation, or a principle on which something is based.
basis.example: The basis for his argument is the evidence provided in the study.

baste.meaning: To sew with long or loose stitches, as for temporary use, or in preparation for gathering the fabric.
baste.example: I need to baste the fabric before stitching it together for the final design.

batch.meaning: The quantity of bread or other baked goods baked at one time.; To aggregate things together into a batch.; Of a process, operating for a defined set of conditions, and then halting.
batch.example: We made a batch of cookies to take to the party.

bathe.meaning: The act of swimming or bathing, especially in the sea, a lake, or a river; a swimming bath.; To clean oneself by immersion in water or using water; to take a bath, have a bath.
bathe.example: I'm going to have a midnight bathe tonight.

baton.meaning: A staff or truncheon, used for various purposes; To strike with a baton.
baton.example: The officer carried a baton as part of his uniform.

batty.example: He’s acting batty after staying up all night.

bawdy.meaning: Soiled, dirty; crude or vulgar in a humorous or sexual way.
bawdy.example: The comedian's bawdy jokes caused the audience to laugh nervously.

bayou.meaning: A slow-moving, often stagnant creek or river.
bayou.example: We paddled our canoe down the peaceful bayou.

beach.meaning: The shore of a body of water, especially when sandy or pebbly.; To run aground on a beach.; A gravel-filled zone on a racetrack, used as a hazard, exclusionary region, and safety device to slow down and trap vehicles.
beach.example: We spent the afternoon lounging on the beach.

beady.meaning: Resembling beads; small, round, and gleaming.
beady.example: She had beady eyes that sparkled in the sunlight.

beard.meaning: Facial hair on the chin, cheeks, jaw, and neck.; To grow hair on the chin and jaw.
beard.example: He decided to grow a beard for the winter.

beast.meaning: Any animal other than a human; usually only applied to land vertebrates, especially large or dangerous four-footed ones.; To impose arduous exercises, either as training or as punishment.; (chiefly Midwestern and northeastern US) great; excellent; powerful.
beast.example: The lion is considered the beast of the savannah.

beech.meaning: A tree of the genus Fagus having a smooth, light grey trunk, oval, pointed leaves, and many branches.
beech.example: The beech tree provided a perfect spot for our picnic.

beefy.meaning: Similar to, or tasting like beef.
beefy.example: The beefy stew was perfect for a cold evening.

befit.example: His conduct was not befitting an officer of his station.

began.meaning: To start, to initiate or take the first step into something.
began.example: I began playing the piano at the age of five. Now that everyone is here, we should begin the presentation.

begat.meaning: An element of a lineage, especially of a lineage given in the Bible; To father; to sire; to produce (a child).
begat.example: The Bible mentions who begat whom in genealogical lines.

beget.meaning: To father; to sire; to produce (a child).
beget.example: He was the first to beget a child in the family after many generations.

begin.meaning: To start, to initiate or take the first step into something.
begin.example: I will begin my workout as soon as I finish this chapter.

begun.meaning: The past participle of 'begin'; used to describe an action that has started but not yet completed.
begun.example: I have begun reading the new book you gave me.

being.meaning: A living creature; the state of existing; existence.
being.example: Human beings are capable of complex thought and emotions.

belch.meaning: The sound one makes when belching; to expel (gas) loudly from the stomach through the mouth.
belch.example: He couldn't help but belch after drinking the soda.

belie.meaning: To give a false impression of; to lie about something.
belie.example: Her calm demeanor belied her nervousness inside.

belle.example: In her new dress, she felt like the belle of the ball.

belly.meaning: The abdomen, especially a fat one; to position one’s belly; to move on one’s belly.
belly.example: The baby’s belly was full after finishing the bottle.

below.meaning: In a lower place; lower in spatial position than.
below.example: The treasure chest is buried below the ground.

bench.meaning: A long seat with or without a back, found for example in parks and schools; to remove a player from play.
bench.example: They sat on a park bench and tossed bread crumbs to the ducks and pigeons.

beret.meaning: A type of round, brimless cap with a soft top and a headband to secure it to the head; usually culturally associated with France.
beret.example: She wore a red beret that complemented her outfit.

berry.meaning: A small, succulent fruit, of any one of many varieties; to pick berries.
berry.example: We spent the afternoon picking berries in the garden.

berth.meaning: A fixed bunk for sleeping (in caravans, trains, etc); to bring (a ship or vehicle) into its berth.
berth.example: The captain instructed the crew to prepare the ship for its berth at the dock.

beset.example: The town was beset by heavy rain and flooding for days.

betel.meaning: Either of two plants often used in combination, primarily for their leaves which are chewed for their stimulant effects.
betel.example: He offered me a leaf of betel to chew as part of the tradition.

bevel.meaning: An edge that is canted, one that is not a 90-degree angle; a chamfer; to give a canted edge to a surface.

bezel.meaning: The sloping edge or face on a cutting tool; also refers to the edge of a watch or a gemstone setting.

bible.meaning: An exemplar of the Bible; a piece of soft sandstone used for scouring the wooden decks of ships.

bicep.meaning: A muscle located at the front of the upper arm, responsible for flexing the arm.
bicep.example: He flexed his biceps proudly after lifting the heavy weights.

biddy.meaning: A woman, especially an old woman; regarded as fussy, mean, or gossipy.

bigot.meaning: One who is narrow-mindedly devoted to one's own ideas and intolerant of others.

bilge.meaning: The rounded portion of a ship's hull, forming a transition between the bottom and the sides; to spring a leak in the bilge.
bilge.example: The ship took on water through the bilge after hitting the rocks.

billy.example: The police officer carried a billy for self-defense.

binge.meaning: A short period of excessive consumption, especially of food, alcohol, narcotics, etc.; to engage in a short period of excessive consumption, especially of excessive alcohol consumption.
binge.example: She went on a binge after the stressful week at work.

bingo.meaning: A game of chance for two or more players, who mark off numbers on a grid as they are announced by the caller; the game is won by the first person to call out 'bingo!' or 'house!' after crossing off all numbers on the grid or in one line of the grid; to play the game of bingo; just sufficient to return to base (or, alternatively, to divert to an alternative airfield). Used by players of bingo to claim a win.
bingo.example: After marking off all the numbers, she yelled 'Bingo!' and won the game.

biome.meaning: Any major regional biological community such as that of forest or desert.
biome.example: The Amazon Rainforest is one of the most biodiverse biomes on Earth.

birch.meaning: Any of various trees of the genus Betula, native to countries in the Northern Hemisphere; to punish with a stick, bundle of twigs, or rod made of birch wood.
birch.example: The children carved their names into the bark of a birch tree.

birth.meaning: The process of childbearing; the beginning of life; to bear or give birth to (a child); a familial relationship established by childbirth.
birth.example: The birth of their first child was a joyous occasion for the family.

bison.example: We spotted a herd of bison while driving through the national park.

bitty.meaning: (often in the plural) bitch, girl, woman, especially one that is promiscuous; containing bits, fragmented.
bitty.example: He's got it made, hanging around with the bitties all the time.

black.meaning: The colour/color perceived in the absence of light, but also when no light is reflected, but rather absorbed; to make black; to blacken; (of an object) absorbing all light and reflecting none, dark and hueless.
black.example: The night sky was pitch black, with not a star in sight.

blade.meaning: The sharp cutting edge of a knife, chisel, or other tool, a razor blade/sword; to skate on rollerblades; a kind of piton used in thin cracks.

blame.example: She blamed herself for the mistake, even though it wasn't her fault.

bland.meaning: Having a soothing effect; not irritating or stimulating.
bland.example: The soup was rather bland, so I added some seasoning.

blank.meaning: A small French coin, originally of silver, afterwards of copper, worth 5 deniers; also a silver coin of Henry V current in the parts of France then held by the English, worth about 8 pence; to make void; to erase; white or pale, without colour.
blank.example: She stared at the blank sheet of paper, unsure of where to begin.

blare.meaning: A loud sound; to make a loud sound.
blare.example: The blare of the car horn startled everyone on the street.

blast.example: A blast of cold air swept through the open window.

blaze.meaning: A fire, especially a fast-burning fire producing a lot of flames and light.
blaze.example: The blaze from the campfire illuminated the forest around us.

bleak.example: The bleak winter landscape seemed endless.

bleat.meaning: The characteristic cry of a sheep or a goat; of a sheep or goat, to make its characteristic cry; of a human, to mimic this sound.
bleat.example: We could hear the faint bleat of the sheep in the distance.

bleed.meaning: An incident of bleeding, as in haemophilia; (of a person or animal) to lose blood through an injured blood vessel.
bleed.example: The cut was deep enough to make him bleed profusely.

bleep.meaning: A brief high-pitched sound, as from some electronic device; to emit one or more bleeps.

blend.meaning: A mixture of two or more things; to mingle, to mix, to unite intimately; to pass or shade insensibly into each other.
blend.example: Our department has a good blend of experienced workers and young promise.

bless.meaning: To make something holy by religious rite, sanctify.
bless.example: The priest blessed the congregation during the ceremony.

blimp.meaning: An airship constructed with a non-rigid lifting agent container; to expand like a blimp or balloon; to become fat.
blimp.example: The blimp floated above the stadium during the game.

blind.meaning: A covering for a window to keep out light. blink.meaning: The act of very quickly closing both eyes and opening them again; to close and reopen both eyes quickly.

bliss.example: They spent their vacation in bliss, enjoying the peace and quiet of the beach.

blitz.meaning: A sudden attack, especially an air raid; usually with reference to the Blitz; to attack quickly or suddenly, as by an air raid or similar action.

bloat.meaning: Distention of the abdomen from death; to cause to become distended; bloated.

block.meaning: A substantial, often approximately cuboid, piece of any substance; to fill (something) so that it is not possible to pass.

bloke.meaning: A man, a fellow; an ordinary man, a man on the street.

blond.meaning: A pale yellowish (golden brown) color, especially said of hair color; to color or dye blond; of a bleached or pale golden (light yellowish) colour; (especially of a woman) stupid, ignorant, naive.

blood.meaning: A member of the Los Angeles gang The Bloods; a vital liquid flowing in the bodies of many types of animals that usually conveys nutrients and oxygen. In vertebrates, it is colored red by hemoglobin, is conveyed by arteries and veins, is pumped by the heart and is usually generated in bone marrow; to cause something to be covered with blood; to bloody.
blood.example: The crime scene was covered in blood after the violent altercation.

bloom.meaning: A blossom; the flower of a plant; an expanded bud.

blown.meaning: To produce an air current; to blossom; to cause to bloom or blossom; distended, swollen, or inflated.

bluff.meaning: An act of bluffing; a false expression of the strength of one's position in order to intimidate; braggadocio; to make a bluff; to give the impression that one's hand is stronger than it is.

blunt.meaning: A fencer's practice foil with a soft tip; having a thick edge or point; not sharp.

blurb.meaning: A short description of a book, film, or other work, written and used for promotional purposes; to write or quote in a blurb.

blurt.meaning: An abrupt outburst; to utter suddenly and unadvisedly; to speak quickly or without thought; to divulge inconsiderately — commonly with out.

blush.meaning: An act of blushing; a red glow on the face caused by shame, modesty, etc.; to become red in the face (and sometimes experience an associated feeling of warmth), especially due to shyness, shame, excitement, or embarrassment.

board.meaning: A relatively long, wide and thin piece of any material, usually wood or similar, often for use in construction or furniture-making; to step or climb onto or otherwise enter a ship, aircraft, train, or other conveyance.

boast.meaning: A brag; ostentatious positive appraisal of oneself; to brag; to talk loudly in praise of oneself.

bobby.example: The bobby stopped the car for a routine check.

boney.meaning: Having or resembling bones; thin or gaunt.

bongo.meaning: A striped bovine mammal found in Africa, Tragelaphus eurycerus.

bonus.meaning: Something extra that is good; an added benefit; to pay a bonus, premium.
bonus.example: The company gave each employee a bonus for their hard work.

booby.meaning: A stupid person; to behave stupidly; to act like a booby.

boost.meaning: A push from behind, as to one who is endeavoring to climb; to lift or push from behind (one who is endeavoring to climb); to push up.

booth.meaning: A small stall for the display and sale of goods.

booty.meaning: A form of prize which, when a ship was captured at sea, could be distributed at once.

booze.meaning: Any alcoholic beverage; to drink alcohol.

boozy.example: He was acting boozy after the party.

borax.meaning: A white or gray/grey crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste, used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors/colours on porcelain, and as a soap, etc.

borne.meaning: To carry or convey, literally or figuratively; carried, supported.

bosom.meaning: (somewhat obsolete) The breast or chest of a human (or sometimes of another animal); to enclose or carry in the bosom; to keep with care; to take to heart; to cherish; in a very close relationship.

bossy.meaning: Tending to give orders to others, especially when unwarranted; domineering.

botch.meaning: An action, job, or task that has been performed very badly; a ruined, defective, or clumsy piece of work; to perform (a task) in an unacceptable or incompetent manner; to make a mess of something.
botch.example: She botched the presentation by forgetting key points.

bough.meaning: A firm branch of a tree.
bough.example: When the bough breaks, the cradle will fall.

boule.meaning: One of the bowls used in the French game of boules; to shape (a piece of dough) into a ball.
boule.example: He rolled the boule across the court during the game.

bound.meaning: To tie; to confine by any ligature.; (with infinitive) Obliged (to).
bound.example: She felt bound to help her friend in need.

bowel.meaning: A part or division of the intestines, usually the large intestine.; To disembowel.
bowel.example: The doctor explained that the bowel is crucial for digestion.

boxer.meaning: A participant (fighter) in a boxing match.

brace.meaning: Armor for the arm; vambrace.; To prepare for something bad, such as an impact or blow.

braid.meaning: To interweave strands of hair or other materials.; To make a sudden movement with, to jerk.
braid.example: She decided to braid her hair for the party.

brain.meaning: The control center of the central nervous system of an animal located in the skull which is responsible for perception, cognition, attention, memory, emotion, and action.; To dash out the brains of; to kill by smashing the skull.
brain.example: The brain is responsible for all our thoughts and actions.

brake.meaning: A device for slowing or stopping a vehicle.; To slow down or stop a vehicle.

brand.meaning: A conflagration; a flame.; To burn the flesh with a hot iron, either as a marker (for criminals, slaves etc.) or to cauterise a wound.

brash.meaning: Overly bold or self-assertive to the point of being insensitive, tactless or impudent; shameless.

brass.meaning: A metallic alloy of copper and zinc used in many industrial and plumbing applications.; To coat with brass.; Made of brass, of or pertaining to brass.
brass.example: The door handles were made of polished brass.

brave.meaning: Strong in the face of fear; courageous.; A Native American warrior.
brave.example: The firefighter was brave in rescuing the child from the fire.

bravo.meaning: Used to express acclaim, especially to a performer.; A hired soldier; an assassin; a desperado.
bravo.example: The audience shouted 'bravo!' after the stunning performance.

brawl.meaning: A disorderly argument or fight, usually with a large number of people involved.; To engage in a brawl; to fight or quarrel.

brawn.meaning: Strong muscles or lean flesh, especially of the arm, leg or thumb.; Make fat, especially of a boar.

bread.meaning: A foodstuff made by baking dough made from cereals.; To coat with breadcrumbs.

break.meaning: An instance of breaking something into two or more pieces.; To separate into two or more pieces, to fracture or crack, by a process that cannot easily be reversed for reassembly.

breed.meaning: All animals or plants of the same species or subspecies.; To produce offspring sexually; to bear young.

briar.meaning: Any of many plants with thorny stems growing in dense clusters, such as many in the Rosa, Rubus, and Smilax genera.

bribe.meaning: Something (usually money) given in exchange for influence or as an inducement to dishonesty.; To give a bribe to; specifically, to ask a person to do something, usually against his/her will, in exchange for some type of reward or relief from potential trouble.

brick.meaning: A hardened rectangular block of mud, clay etc., used for building.; To build with bricks.; (of weather) Extremely cold.

bride.meaning: A woman in the context of her own wedding; one who is going to marry or has just been married.; To make a bride of.
bride.example: The bride walked down the aisle with a radiant smile.

brief.meaning: Of short duration; happening quickly.; To summarize a recent development to some person with decision-making power.
brief.example: The meeting was brief, lasting only fifteen minutes.

brine.meaning: Salt water; water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt; a salt-and-water solution for pickling.; To preserve food in a salt solution.

bring.example: Waiter, please bring me a single malt whiskey.

brink.meaning: The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of a precipice; a bank or edge.

briny.meaning: The sea.; Of, pertaining to, resembling or containing brine; salty.

brisk.meaning: (often with "up") To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate.; Full of liveliness and activity; characterized by quickness of motion or action.
brisk.example: They took a brisk walk in the cool morning air.

broad.meaning: Wide in extent or scope.; A shallow lake, one of a number of bodies of water in eastern Norfolk and Suffolk.

broil.meaning: Food prepared by broiling.; To cook by direct, radiant heat.

broke.meaning: Financially ruined, bankrupt.; To separate into two or more pieces, to fracture or crack, by a process that cannot easily be reversed for reassembly.
broke.example: If the vase falls to the floor, it might break.

brood.meaning: The young of certain animals, especially a group of young birds or fowl hatched at one time by the same mother.; To keep an egg warm to make it hatch.; Kept or reared for breeding, said of animals.
brood.example: The hen sat on her brood of chicks.

brook.meaning: To tolerate or allow; to endure.
brook.example: I cannot brook any disrespect in my classroom.

broom.meaning: A domestic utensil with fibers bound together at the end of a long handle, used for sweeping.; To sweep with a broom.
broom.example: She grabbed the broom to clean up the mess.

broth.meaning: Water in which food (meat or vegetable etc) has been boiled.

brown.meaning: A colour like that of chocolate or coffee.; To become brown.; Having a brown colour.

brunt.meaning: The full adverse effects; the chief consequences or negative results of a thing or event.; To bear the brunt of; to weather or withstand.

brush.meaning: An implement consisting of multiple more or less flexible bristles or other filaments attached to a handle, used for any of various purposes including cleaning, painting, and arranging hair.; To clean with a brush.

brute.meaning: An animal seen as being without human reason; a senseless beast.; Without reason or intelligence (of animals).

buddy.meaning: A friend or casual acquaintance.; To assign a buddy, or partner, to.

buggy.meaning: A small horse-drawn cart.; Infested with insects.

bugle.meaning: A horn used by hunters.; To announce, sing, or cry in the manner of a musical bugle.

build.meaning: The physique of a human body; constitution or structure of a human body.; To form (something) by combining materials or parts.

built.meaning: Well-built, muscular or toned.; To form (something) by combining materials or parts.

bulge.meaning: Something sticking out from a surface; a swelling, protuberant part; a bending outward, especially when caused by pressure.; To stick out from (a surface).

bulky.meaning: Being large in size, mass, or volume.
bulky.example: The bulky package was difficult to carry.

bully.meaning: A person who is intentionally, physically, or emotionally cruel to others; especially to those who are weaker or have less power or privilege.; To intimidate (someone) as a bully.; Very good.; (often followed by for) Well done!

bunch.meaning: A group of similar things, either growing together, or in a cluster or clump, usually fastened together.; To gather into a bunch.
bunch.example: I bought a bunch of flowers for the table.

bunny.meaning: A rabbit, especially a juvenile.; Easy or unchallenging.

burly.meaning: (usually of a man) Large, well-built, and muscular.

burnt.meaning: To cause to be consumed by fire.; Damaged or injured by fire or heat.

burst.meaning: An act or instance of bursting.; To break from internal pressure.

bused.meaning: To transport via a motor bus.

bushy.meaning: Like a bush in having many widely spread branches.

butch.meaning: A lesbian who appears masculine or acts in a masculine manner.; (originally Polari) Very masculine, with a masculine appearance or attitude.
butch.example: She has a butch style that challenges traditional gender norms.

butte.meaning: An isolated hill with steep sides and a flat top.

buxom.meaning: Pliant, obedient, tractable (to) (i.e. easily moved or bent, morally).

buyer.meaning: A person who makes one or more purchases.
buyer.example: Every person who steps through the door is a potential buyer, so acknowledge their presence.

bylaw.meaning: A local custom or law of a settlement or district.
bylaw.example: The town council passed a bylaw to regulate noise levels.

cabal.meaning: # A putative, secret organization of individuals gathered for a political purpose.; To engage in the activities of a cabal.
cabal.example: The cabal is plotting to influence the election.

cabby.meaning: A cabdriver; someone who drives a taxi.

cabin.meaning: A small dwelling characteristic of the frontier, especially when built from logs with simple tools and not constructed by professional builders, but by those who meant to live in it.; To place in a cabin or other small space.
cabin.example: Abraham Lincoln was born in a log cabin.

cable.meaning: (material) A long object used to make a physical connection.; To provide with cable(s)

cacao.meaning: A tree, Theobroma cacao, whose seed is used to make chocolate.

caddy.meaning: One hired to assist another in playing the game of golf.; To serve as a caddy, carrying golf clubs etc.

cadet.meaning: A student at a military school who is training to be an officer.

cagey.example: He was cagey about revealing his plans.

cairn.meaning: A rounded or conical heap of stones erected by early inhabitants of the British Isles, apparently as a sepulchral monument.

camel.meaning: A beast of burden, much used in desert areas, of the genus Camelus.; Of a light brown color like that of a camel.
camel.example: The camel is often referred to as the ship of the desert.

cameo.meaning: A piece of jewelry, etc., carved in relief.; To appear in a cameo role.

canal.meaning: An artificial waterway or artificially improved river used for travel, shipping, or irrigation.; To dig an artificial waterway in or to (a place), especially for drainage.

candy.meaning: Edible, sweet-tasting confectionery containing sugar, or sometimes artificial sweeteners, and often flavored with fruit, chocolate, nuts, herbs and spices, or artificial flavors.; To cook in, or coat with, sugar syrup.

canny.meaning: Careful, prudent, cautious.; Very, considerably; quite, rather.

The paddlers face in the direction of travel, in either a seated position, or kneeling on the bottom of the boat. Canoes are open on top, and pointed at both ends.; To ride or paddle a canoe.
canoe.example: We decided to canoe down the river for the afternoon.

caput.meaning: The head or chief part of something.

carat.meaning: A unit of weight for precious stones and pearls, equivalent to 200 milligrams.

carol.meaning: A song of joy or praise, especially one sung at Christmas.
carol.example: They sang a beautiful carol during the holiday season.

carry.meaning: A manner of transporting or lifting something; the grip or position in which something is carried.; To lift (something) and take it to another place; to transport (something) by lifting.

cause.meaning: (often with of, typically of adverse results) The source of, or reason for, an event or action; that which produces or effects a result.; To set off an event or action.

debug.meaning: The action, or a session, of reviewing source code to find and eliminate errors; to search for and eliminate malfunctioning elements or errors in something, especially a computer program or machinery.
debug.example: The software developers spent hours debugging the application.

debut.meaning: A performer's first performance to the public, in sport, the arts or some other area; to formally introduce, as to the public.
debut.example: Her debut performance was met with critical acclaim.

decal.meaning: A design or picture produced in order to be transferred to another surface either permanently or temporarily; to apply decals to.
decal.example: The car had a cool decal of a racing stripe on the hood.

decay.meaning: The process or result of being gradually decomposed; to deteriorate, to get worse, to lose strength or health, to decline in quality.
decay.example: The apple started to decay after being left out for too long.

decor.meaning: The style of decoration of a room or building.
decor.example: Her living room had a lush Persian-style decor.

decoy.meaning: A person or object meant to lure somebody into danger; to lead into danger by artifice; to lure into a net or snare; to entrap.
decoy.example: The hunters used a decoy to attract the ducks.

decry.example: The critics decry the use of excessive CGI in movies.

defer.example: We're going to defer the decision until we have all the facts.

deign.meaning: To condescend; to do despite a perceived affront to one's dignity.
deign.example: He didn't even deign to give us a nod of the head; he thought us that far beneath him.

deity.meaning: A supernatural divine being; a god or goddess; the state, position, or fact of being a god or God. [from 14th c.]
deity.example: Many ancient cultures worshiped a variety of deities.

delay.meaning: A period of time before an event occurs; the act of delaying; procrastination; lingering inactivity; to put off until a later time; to defer.
delay.example: The delay before the echo of a sound.

delta.meaning: The fourth letter of the modern Greek alphabet Δ, δ.
delta.example: Delta is often used in scientific terms.

delve.meaning: To dig the ground, especially with a shovel.
delve.example: They decided to delve deeper into the mystery.

demon.example: The story involved a demon that haunted the town.

demur.meaning: Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple; to linger; to stay; to tarry.
demur.example: He demurred at the suggestion, unsure of its implications.

denim.meaning: A textile often made of cotton with a distinct diagonal pattern.
denim.example: She wore her favorite denim jeans to the concert.

dense.meaning: A thicket; having relatively high density.
dense.example: The forest was dense, making it hard to navigate.

depot.meaning: A storage facility, in particular, a warehouse.
depot.example: The goods were stored at the depot before being shipped.

depth.meaning: The vertical distance below a surface; the degree to which something is deep.
depth.example: Measure the depth of the water in this part of the bay.

derby.meaning: Any of several annual horse races.
derby.example: The Kentucky Derby is a famous annual event.

deter.example: The high fence was designed to deter burglars.

detox.meaning: Detoxification, especially of the body from alcohol or illegal, addictive drugs; to detoxify, especially from alcohol or recreational drugs.
detox.example: After weeks of heavy drinking, he decided to detox.

deuce.meaning: A card with two pips, one of four in a standard deck of playing cards.
deuce.example: He played a deuce to win the round.

devil.meaning: An evil creature; to make like a devil; to invest with the character of a devil.
devil.example: The devil tempted him with promises of power.

diary.meaning: A daily log of experiences, especially those of the writer; to keep a diary or journal; lasting for one day.
diary.example: They kept separate diaries. His was on paper, and her diary was on her computer's hard drive.

dicey.example: The situation became dicey when the storm hit.

digit.meaning: A stage of proficiency or qualification in a course of study, now especially an award bestowed by a university or, in some countries, a college, as a certification of academic achievement. (In the United States, can include secondary schools); the whole numbers from 0 to 9 and the Arabic numerals representing them, which are combined to represent base-ten numbers; to point at or point out with the finger; a unit of length equal to one twelfth of a foot, or exactly 2.54 centimeters; a small island.
digit.example: She has two bachelor's degrees and is studying towards a master's degree.

dilly.example: The dish had a dilly flavor from the added herb.

dimly.example: The room was dimly lit by a single candle.

diner.example: The diner enjoyed a hearty breakfast at the cafe.

dingo.meaning: Canis lupus dingo, a wild dog native to Australia.
dingo.example: The dingo is often found in the Australian outback.

dingy.example: The dingy room had peeling wallpaper and dim lighting.

diode.meaning: An electronic device that allows current to flow in one direction only; used chiefly as a rectifier.
diode.example: The diode in the circuit prevents reverse current.

dirge.meaning: A mournful poem or piece of music composed or performed as a memorial to a dead person; to sing dirges.
dirge.example: A somber dirge was played at the funeral.

dirty.meaning: To make (something) dirty; unclean; covered with or containing unpleasant substances such as dirt or grime; in a dirty manner.
dirty.example: The muddy boots made the floor dirty.

disco.meaning: A genre of dance music that was popular in the 1970s, characterized by elements of soul music with a strong Latin-American beat and often accompanied by pulsating lights; to dance disco-style dances; (slightly obsolete) a nightclub where dancing takes place.

ditch.meaning: A trench; a long, shallow indentation, as for irrigation or drainage; to discard or abandon.

ditto.meaning: That which was stated before, the aforesaid, the above, the same, likewise; to repeat the aforesaid, the earlier action etc.; as said before, likewise; used as an expression of agreement with what another person has said, or to indicate that what they have said equally applies to the person being addressed.

ditty.meaning: A short verse or tune; to sing; to warble a little tune.
ditty.example: The Acme mattress ditty has been stuck in my head all day.

diver.meaning: Someone who dives, especially as a sport.
diver.example: The diver explored the coral reef during his vacation.

dizzy.meaning: To make dizzy, to bewilder; having a sensation of whirling, with a tendency to fall; giddy; feeling unbalanced or lightheaded.
dizzy.example: She felt dizzy after spinning around for a while.

dodge.meaning: An act of dodging; to avoid (something) by moving suddenly out of the way; dodgy.
dodge.example: He had to dodge the flying ball during the game.

dodgy.example: Asked why, a spokesman gave a dodgy answer about legal ramifications.

dogma.meaning: An authoritative principle, belief, or statement of opinion, especially one considered to be absolutely true and indisputable, regardless of evidence or without evidence to support it.
dogma.example: The philosopher rejected dogma in favor of rational debate.

doing.meaning: (auxiliary) A syntactic marker; a deed or action, especially when somebody is held responsible for it.
doing.example: Her doing all the work was a surprise to the team.

dolly.meaning: A doll; to hit a dolly.
dolly.example: She played with her dolly all afternoon.

donor.example: The charity raised $2,000 from various donors.

donut.meaning: A deep-fried piece of dough or batter, commonly made in a toroidal or ellipsoidal shape, and mixed with various sweeteners and flavors, sometimes filled with jelly, custard or cream.
donut.example: I enjoyed a chocolate-glazed donut with my coffee this morning.

dopey.example: He made a dopey mistake by not reading the instructions carefully.

doubt.meaning: Disbelief or uncertainty (about something); a particular instance of such disbelief or uncertainty.; To be undecided about; to lack confidence in; to disbelieve, to question.
doubt.example: I have doubts about how to convert this code to JavaScript.

dough.meaning: A thick, malleable substance made by mixing flour with other ingredients such as water, eggs, and/or butter, that is made into a particular form and then baked.; To make into dough.

dowdy.meaning: A plain or shabby person; Plain and unfashionable in style or dress.
dowdy.example: Her dowdy outfit didn't match the vibrant atmosphere of the party.

dowel.meaning: A pin, or block, of wood or metal, fitting into holes in the abutting portions of two pieces, and being partly in one piece and partly in the other, to keep them in their proper relative position.; To fasten together with dowels.
dowel.example: The two pieces of wood were joined together with dowels for extra stability.

downy.meaning: Having down, covered with a soft fuzzy coating as of small feathers or hair.
downy.example: The chick's downy coat of feathers formed almost immediately to keep it warm.

dowry.meaning: Payment, such as property or money, paid by the bride's family to the groom or his family at the time of marriage.; To bestow a dowry upon.
dowry.example: In some cultures, a dowry is still given as part of a marriage arrangement.

dozen.example: Can I have a dozen eggs, please?

draft.meaning: A current of air, usually coming into a room or vehicle.; To write a first version, make a preliminary sketch.; Referring to drinks on tap, in contrast to bottled.
draft.example: I felt a cold draft coming through the open window.

drain.meaning: A conduit allowing liquid to flow out of an otherwise contained volume; a plughole (UK); To lose liquid.
drain.example: The drain in the kitchen sink is clogged.

drake.example: The drake swam confidently in the pond, followed by the female ducks.

drama.meaning: A composition, normally in prose, telling a story and intended to be represented by actors impersonating the characters and speaking the dialogue.
drama.example: The play was an intense drama about love and betrayal.

drank.meaning: Dextromethorphan; To consume (a liquid) through the mouth.
drank.example: She drank a glass of water after her morning run.

drape.meaning: A curtain; a drapery.; To cover or adorn with drapery or folds of cloth, or as with drapery.
drape.example: The elegant drapes added a luxurious touch to the room.

drawl.meaning: A way of speaking slowly while lengthening vowel sounds and running words together. Characteristic of some southern US accents, as well as Scots.; To drag on slowly and heavily; to while or dawdle away time indolently.
drawl.example: She spoke with a slow drawl that made every word sound deliberate.

drawn.meaning: To move or develop something.; Appearing tired and unwell, as from stress; haggard.
drawn.example: His drawn face showed the exhaustion from his long days at work.

dread.meaning: Great fear in view of impending evil; fearful apprehension of danger; anticipatory terror.; To fear greatly.; Terrible; greatly feared.
dread.example: My visit to the doctor is filling me with dread.

dream.meaning: Imaginary events seen in the mind while sleeping.; To see imaginary events in one's mind while sleeping.; Ideal; perfect.
dream.example: Last night, I dreamt I was flying above the clouds.

dress.meaning: An item of clothing (usually worn by a woman or young girl) which both covers the upper part of the body and includes skirts below the waist.; To fit out with the necessary clothing; to clothe, put clothes on (something or someone).
dress.example: Amy and Mary looked very pretty in their dresses.

dried.meaning: Without water or moisture, said of something that has previously been wet or moist; resulting from the process of drying.; To lose moisture.

drier.meaning: One who, or that which, dries; a desiccative.
drier.example: The sun and a northwesterly wind are great driers of the earth.

drift.meaning: (physical) Movement; that which moves or is moved.; To move slowly, especially pushed by currents of water, air, etc.

drill.meaning: A tool used to remove material so as to create a hole, typically by plunging a rotating cutting bit into a stationary workpiece.; To create (a hole) by removing material with a drill (tool).

drink.meaning: To consume (a liquid) through the mouth.
drink.example: He drank the water I gave him.

drive.meaning: Motivation to do or achieve something; ability coupled with ambition.; To provide an impetus for motion or other physical change, to move an object by means of the provision of force thereto.
drive.example: Crassus had wealth and wit, but Pompey had drive and Caesar as much again.

droit.meaning: A legal right or entitlement, especially in French law.

droll.meaning: A funny person; a buffoon, a wag.; To jest, to joke.; Oddly humorous; whimsical, amusing in a quaint way; waggish.

drone.meaning: A male ant, bee or wasp, which does not work but can fertilize the queen bee.; To kill with a missile fired by unmanned aircraft.
drone.example: A drone hovered overhead, capturing footage of the event.

drool.meaning: Saliva trickling from the mouth.; To secrete saliva, especially in anticipation of food.

droop.meaning: Something which is limp or sagging; To hang downward; to sag.

dross.meaning: Waste or impure matter; to remove dross from.

drove.meaning: A number of cattle driven to market or new pastures.

drown.meaning: To die from suffocation while immersed in water or other fluid.

druid.meaning: One of an order of priests among certain groups of Celts before the adoption of Abrahamic religions.

drunk.meaning: To consume (a liquid) through the mouth; one who is intoxicated with alcohol; intoxicated as a result of excessive alcohol consumption, usually by drinking alcoholic beverages.

dryer.meaning: One who, or that which, dries; a desiccative.

dryly.example: He responded dryly, without emotion, to the accusation.

duchy.meaning: A dominion or region ruled by a duke or duchess. (A grand duchy may be a self-governing state. A simple duchy tends to be a part of a larger kingdom or empire.)

dully.meaning: In a dull manner; without liveliness; without lustre.

dummy.meaning: A silent person; a person who does not talk; to make a mock-up or prototype version of something, without some or all of its intended functionality.

dumpy.meaning: A short, stout person or animal, especially one of a breed of very short-legged chickens; short and thick; stout or stocky.

dunce.example: The teacher scolded the dunce for failing the test.

dusky.meaning: A dusky shark; dimly lit, as at dusk (evening).

dusty.example: The old books were dusty and neglected on the shelf.

dutch.example: He called her his Dutch, an affectionate term for his wife.

duvet.meaning: A thick, padded quilt used instead of blankets.
duvet.example: I love curling up in a warm duvet on a cold winter night.

dwarf.meaning: Any member of a race of beings from (especially Scandinavian and other Germanic) folklore, usually depicted as having some sort of supernatural powers and being skilled in crafting and metalworking, often as short with long beards, and sometimes as clashing with elves; to render (much) smaller, turn into a dwarf (version); miniature.

dwell.example: They chose to dwell in the quiet countryside away from the bustling city.

dwelt.example: They dwelt in the village for many years before moving to the city.

dying.meaning: To stop living; to become dead; to undergo death; to colour with dye, or as if with dye; the process of approaching death; loss of life; less precisely, death; (with 'the') those who are currently expiring, moribund; approaching death; about to die; moribund.

eager.example: The eager lemon tart was just the right amount of tangy.

eagle.meaning: Any of several large carnivorous and carrion-eating birds in the family Accipitridae, having a powerful hooked bill and keen vision; to score an eagle.

early.meaning: A shift (scheduled work period) that takes place early in the day; at a time in advance of the usual or expected event; at a time before expected; sooner than usual.

earth.meaning: The third planet of the Solar System; the world upon which humans live; soil; to connect electrically to the earth.

easel.meaning: An upright frame, typically on three legs, for displaying or supporting something, such as an artist's canvas.

eaten.meaning: To ingest; to be ingested; (especially in combination) that has been consumed by eating.

eater.example: The eater of the cake was quickly caught.

ebony.meaning: A hard, dense, deep black wood from various subtropical and tropical trees, especially of the genus Diospyros.; Made of ebony wood.

eclat.meaning: A brilliant or successful effect; brilliance of success or effort; splendor; brilliant show; striking effect; glory; renown.

edict.meaning: A proclamation of law or other authoritative command.

eerie.example: The eerie sounds seemed to come from the graveyard after midnight.

egret.meaning: Any of various wading birds of the genera Egretta or Ardea that includes herons, many of which are white or buff, and several of which develop fine plumes during the breeding season.

eight.meaning: The digit/figure 8.; A numerical value equal to 8; the number occurring after seven and before nine.; The ordinal form of the number eight.
eight.example: There are eight apples in the basket.

eject.meaning: To compel (a person or persons) to leave.
eject.example: Andrew was ejected from his apartment for not paying the rent.

eking.meaning: The act or process of adding.

elate.meaning: To make joyful or proud.; Elated; exultant
elate.example: She was elated after receiving the promotion.

elbow.meaning: The joint between the upper arm and the forearm.; To push with the elbow.
elbow.example: She elbowed her way through the crowded hall.

elder.meaning: An older person or an older member, usually a leader, of some community.; To admonish or reprove for improper conduct by the elders of the meeting.; Of an object, concept, relationship, etc., having existed for a relatively long period of time.
elder.example: We were presented to the village elder.

elect.meaning: One chosen or set apart.; To choose or make a decision (to do something); Who has been elected in a specified post, but has not yet entered office.

elegy.meaning: A mournful or plaintive poem; a funeral song; a poem of lamentation.

elfin.meaning: An elf; an inhabitant of fairy-land.

elite.meaning: A special group or social class of people which have a superior intellectual, social or economic status as, the elite of society.; Of high birth or social position; aristocratic or patrician.

elope.meaning: (of a married person) To run away from home with a paramour.
elope.example: The couple decided to elope to Las Vegas.

elude.meaning: To evade, or escape from someone or something, especially by using cunning or skill
elude.example: The fugitive managed to elude capture for months.

email.meaning: A system for transferring messages from one computer to another, usually through a network.; To send an email or emails to.
email.example: He sent me his details via email.

embed.meaning: An embedded reporter or journalist, such as a war reporter assigned to and travelling with a military unit, or a political reporter assigned to follow and report on the campaign of a candidate.; To lay as in a bed; to lay in surrounding matter; to bed.

ember.meaning: A glowing piece of coal or wood.
ember.example: The ember from the fire glowed softly in the dark.

emcee.meaning: A rapper.; A medical facility, such as a hospital, especially one for the treatment and diagnosis of outpatients.; To act as the master of ceremonies (for).; A large medical facility, usually in a building with multiple floors, where seriously ill or injured patients are given extensive medical and/or surgical treatment.; Someone who acts as a host at a formal event.; Dichloromethane; A viral infection of the skin or (occasionally) mucous membranes, caused by Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), a DNA poxvirus.; A group of individuals whose primary interests and activities involve motorcycles.; A place used as a hospital on board a ship, on a spaceship (in science fiction).

emoji.meaning: A small digital image or icon used to express an idea, emotion, or concept in electronic communication.; A symbolic representation of a facial expression, object, or concept, typically used in text messages, social media, and emails.

empty.meaning: (usually plural) A container, especially a bottle, whose contents have been used up, leaving it empty.; To make empty; to void; to remove the contents of.; Devoid of content; containing nothing or nobody; vacant.
empty.example: Put the empties out to be recycled.

enact.meaning: Purpose; determination; To make (a bill) into law.
enact.example: The government is set to enact new environmental regulations.

endow.meaning: To provide with a dower or a dowry.
endow.example: The charity was endowed with a generous gift from a benefactor.

enema.meaning: An injection of fluid into the large intestine by way of the rectum, usually for medical purposes.
enema.example: The doctor recommended an enema to relieve constipation.

enemy.meaning: Someone who is hostile to, feels hatred towards, opposes the interests of, or intends injury to someone else.; To make an enemy of.; Of, relating to, or belonging to an enemy.

enjoy.meaning: To receive pleasure or satisfaction from something

ennui.meaning: A gripping listlessness or melancholia caused by boredom; depression. To make bored or listless; to weary.
ennui.example: The endless meetings filled him with a sense of ennui.

enter.meaning: The 'Enter' key on a computer keyboard; to go or come into an enclosed or partially enclosed space.
enter.example: Please press 'Enter' to submit the form.

entry.example: Her entry into the competition was well-received.

envoy.meaning: A short stanza at the end of a poem, used either to address a person or to comment on the preceding body of the poem; A diplomatic agent of the second rank, next in status after an ambassador.

epoch.meaning: A particular period of history, especially one considered noteworthy or remarkable; To divide (data) into segments by time period.
epoch.example: The Victorian era was an epoch of rapid industrial growth.

epoxy.meaning: A thermosetting polyepoxide resin used chiefly in strong adhesives, coatings and laminates; epoxy resin; To glue with epoxy; Derived from an epoxide.

equal.meaning: A person or thing of equal status to others; To be equal to, to have the same value as; to correspond to; The same in all respects.

equip.meaning: To supply with something necessary in order to carry out a specific action or task; to provide with (e.g., weapons, provisions, munitions, rigging).
equip.example: The soldiers were equipped with the latest gear.

erase.meaning: The operation of deleting data; To remove markings or information.
erase.example: I need to erase these files from my computer.

erect.meaning: Upright; vertical or reaching broadly upwards.
erect.example: The statue stood erect in the middle of the square.

erode.meaning: To wear away by abrasion, corrosion or chemical reaction.
erode.example: The coastline erodes slowly over time due to the waves.

error.meaning: The state, quality, or condition of being wrong; To function improperly due to an error, especially accompanied by error message.

erupt.meaning: To eject something violently (such as lava or water, as from a volcano or geyser).

essay.meaning: (authorship) A written composition of moderate length, exploring a particular issue or subject.

ester.meaning: A compound most often formed by the condensation of an alcohol and an acid, with elimination of water, which contains the functional group carbon-oxygen double bond joined via carbon to another oxygen atom.

ethic.meaning: A set of principles of right and wrong behaviour guiding, or representative of, a specific culture, society, group, or individual; Moral, relating to morals.

etude.meaning: A short piece of music, designed to give a performer practice in a particular area or skill.

evade.meaning: To get away from by cunning; to avoid by dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to cleverly escape from.

event.meaning: An occurrence; something that happens; To occur, take place.

every.meaning: Used to refer to all the individual members of a group or thing.

evict.meaning: To expel (one or more people) from their property; to force (one or more people) to move out.
evict.example: The landlord decided to evict the tenants for not paying rent.

evoke.meaning: To call out; to draw out or bring forth.
evoke.example: The smell of fresh bread evoked memories of my childhood.

exalt.meaning: To honor; to hold in high esteem.

excel.meaning: To surpass someone or something; to be better or do better than someone or something.

exert.example: I exerted myself in today's training.

exile.meaning: The state of being banished from one's home or country; To send into exile.

exist.meaning: (stative) to be; have existence; have being or reality.
exist.example: Do you think extraterrestrial life exists?

expel.example: They were expelled from the school for cheating.

extol.example: The teacher extolled the student's hard work.

extra.meaning: Something additional, such as an item above and beyond the ordinary school curriculum, or added to the usual charge on a bill; Beyond what is due, usual, expected, or necessary; extraneous; additional; supernumerary.
extra.example: She had to pay extra for the additional baggage.

exult.meaning: To rejoice; to be very happy, especially in triumph.

fable.meaning: A fictitious narrative intended to enforce some useful truth or precept, usually with animals, etc. as characters; an apologue. Prototypically, Aesop's Fables; To compose fables; hence, to write or speak fiction; to write or utter what is not true.

facet.meaning: Any one of the flat surfaces cut into a gem.; To cut a facet into a gemstone.

faint.meaning: The act of fainting, syncope.; (of a being) Lacking strength; weak; languid; inclined to lose consciousness

fairy.meaning: The realm of faerie; enchantment, illusion; Like a fairy; fanciful, whimsical, delicate.

faith.meaning: A trust or confidence in the intentions or abilities of a person, object, or ideal from prior empirical evidence.
faith.example: I have faith in the goodness of my fellow man.

wrath.meaning: Great anger.; To anger; to enrage.; Wrathful; wroth; very angry.
wrath.example: Homer relates an episode in the Trojan War that reveals the tragic consequences of the wrath of Achilles.

wreak.meaning: To cause something harmful; to afflict; to inflict; to harm or injury; to let out something harmful; .
wreak.example: She wreaked her anger on his car.

wreck.meaning: Something or someone that has been ruined.; To destroy violently; to cause severe damage to something, to a point where it no longer works, or is useless.
wreck.example: He was an emotional wreck after the death of his wife.

wrest.meaning: The act of wresting; a wrench or twist; distortion.; To pull or twist violently.

wring.meaning: A powerful squeezing or twisting action.; To squeeze or twist (something) tightly so that liquid is forced out. See also wring out.
wring.example: I grasped his hand and gave it a grateful wring.

wrist.meaning: The complex joint between forearm bones, carpus, and metacarpals where the hand is attached to the arm; the carpus in a narrow sense.; To hit a wrist shot

write.meaning: The act or style of writing.; To form letters, words or symbols on a surface in order to communicate.

wrong.meaning: Something that is immoral or not good.; To treat unjustly; to injure or harm.; Incorrect or untrue.; In a way that isn't right; incorrectly, wrongly.

wrote.meaning: To form letters, words or symbols on a surface in order to communicate.
wrote.example: The pupil wrote his name on the paper.

wrung.meaning: To squeeze or twist (something) tightly so that liquid is forced out. See also wring out.
wrung.example: I didn’t have a towel so I just wrung my hair dry.

wryly.example: 1966: The sins of the father, she thought wryly. Well, they had visited Tony, all right — only he didn't know it. — Jacqueline Susann, Valley of the Dolls (Grove Press 1997, p. 206)

yacht.meaning: A slick and light ship for making pleasure trips or racing on water, having sails but often motor-powered. At times used as a residence offshore on a dock.; To sail, voyage, or race in a yacht.
yacht.example: Would you like to go sailing on my uncle’s yacht?

yearn.meaning: To long, have a strong desire (for something).
yearn.example: All I yearn for is a simple life.

yeast.meaning: An often humid, yellowish froth produced by fermenting malt worts, and used to brew beer, leaven bread, and also used in certain medicines.; To ferment.

yield.meaning: To pay, give in payment; repay, recompense; reward; requite.

young.meaning: People who are young; young people, collectively; youth.; To become or seem to become younger.; In the early part of growth or life; born not long ago.
young.example: The young of today are well-educated.

youth.meaning: The quality or state of being young.
youth.example: Her youth and beauty attracted him to her.

zebra.meaning: Any of three species of genus Equus: E. grevyi, E. quagga, or E. zebra, all with black and white stripes and native to Africa.
